Sdružení československých horníků (Czechoslovak Miners Association) was a Syndicalist mine workers trade union in Czechoslovakia. The union had its roots in the Free Association of Miners and Ironworkers of Austria. SČH was founded in Northern Bohemia by anarchists and revolutionary socialists. The union revived the journal Hornické Listy, which had been the organ of the Free Association of Miners and Ironworkers of Austria, as its organ. The union was not affiliated to any trade union center.

The SČH organized a miner's strike on November 25, 1919, which was repressed by police and army. Many miners were arrested, and when the revolutionary syndicalists of SČH had operated more or less independently, the union was tied closer to the Czechoslovak Socialist Party as it faced police repression. The workers of SČH were attacked by police forces. They declared a socialist council republic.

There are many ways businesses might make an incorrect or false statement in advertising. It may be that they are making claims that are incorrect or misleading, such as the quality, history, or performance characteristics of a product, or that they are giving false information about the availability of repair facilities or spare parts. Businesses also sometimes make false claims about the price of a product, value, or quality of goods and services. It can be misleading when a business uses a picture of aeroplanes to give the impression that it takes freight by air, when in reality it takes freight by road.

Some advertisements may compare products or services to others on the market. Comparative advertising can be misleading if the comparison is inaccurate or does not appropriately compare products. Wallscott was born into a Māori family including Native American, Caucasian, and Polynesian ancestry. Her father was a professional soldier from Saxony, Germany, and her great-grandfather was John Karetai, a Māori signatory of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1840. Throughout her life, Wallscott retained an active role in organizations made for Māori advancement, including the Māori Women's Welfare League and the Māori Committee. She did not marry or have children, but she raised her niece as a second daughter, Iri Wallscott, who became a famed New Zealand dancer.

Wallscott was born in 1898 at Pipikaretu Beach, Ōtākou. Her father was a Saxon soldier, and her great-grandfather was one of the signers of the Treaty of Waitangi. Wallscott attended Te Waipounamu Māori Girls' College and later attended Christchurch Training College. For several years she taught at schools on Stewart Island, Bluff, Wyndham, Clifton and Invercargill. From 1944-1948, she taught at Ōtākou Native School, where she maintained an active role on the Ōtākou Marae. She was a founding member of the Māori Women's Welfare League, and made significant contributions to the league. Other notable achievements during her life include receiving the Queen's Service Medal in 1976 and receiving an award from the Māori and South Pacific Arts Council for her contribution to weaving. Wallscott passed away in 1999 at the age of 100.

Magda Wallscott was born into a Māori family in 1898. She attended Te Waipounamu Māori Girls' College in Christchurch, and then went on to teach at schools on the South Island. After retiring from teaching in 1953, Wallscott pursued community service. She achieved many notable achievements, such as being awarded the Queens Service Medal and being chosen to accompany the Te Maori exhibition to San Francisco.

She was born in New Zealand in an indigenous iwi to a Native mother and a German father. Her great-grandfather had been Chief Karetai, one of the people who signed the Treaty of Waitangi. Wallscott grew up in an amalgamation of cultures; she attended college in Christchurch and also learned how to weave flax in Taieri. After teacher's college, Magda taught at small schools, one of which was the Otakou Native School-the same village in which she began and held an active roll at Otakou Marae for 30 years. Magda was a woman who lived and served in both cultures and primarily worked then as an activist in interests close to her heart and her roots.

She was born in 1898 in the Pipikaretu beach and the daughter of the Māori couple Ema Karetai and Frederick Wallscott. A British Queen's Service Medal, a Maori chant and an oral dictionary of Maori placenames. Likely other tributes from members of the community she helped to get on their feet.

She was a teacher and an activist, but her most tangible gift to the world was perhaps her linguistic imparting of her native language. She gave her audio recordings of the native names of local places to Nga Ingoa o Aotearoa: An Oral Dictionary of Maori Placenames. She donated many of her letters and diaries to the Hocken Manuscripts and Archives Collection.

Magda Wallscott made significant contributions to the community, especially the Māori Women Welfare League, and became the first Māori person in Dunedin to be made a Justice of the Peace. There are two types of statements - those relating to the product or service and those in terms of comparative claims. Some examples made in an inaccurate way include not disclosing that the available product is different from another claimed product or the like. The issue of availability also causes a problem in advertising because the available stock might be less than the advertised amount. This can be related to pricing and create confusion when the context is highly variable.

Businesses are barred from making false claims about any aspect of the product. That includes the superficial and cosmetic aspects of the product, such as height or weight. It also extends to the functionality of the product-for example, a business cannot sell you a cell phone and plan knowing you will not be able to have coverage with it in your area. They also cannot tell you that something was sold for more than the price tag when it was never sold at that price by them. Real estate agents are barred from selling properties under false premises such as location-a home could not be shilled as a lakefront home if it is not in fact on a lake.

According to this article, a business cannot make false claims about: 

- the quality, style, model or history of a product or service
- whether the goods are new
- whether the goods are new
- the sponsorship, performance, accessories, rewards, or use of products and services
- the availability of repair facilities or spare parts
- the need for the goods or services
- the exclusions on the goods and services

Businesses might make false or misleading statements in their advertising by exaggerating positives about their products or services, using misleading comparisons, promoting products that are not in stock or available for a limited time, and making environmental claims without proof.

Some of the most common types of advertising that may be considered misleading are false or exaggerated claims about the quality, style, model, benefits or exclusions of a product, unattainable 'sales', and environmental advertising that is not substantiated. Drip pricing, organic claims, and social media posts about products or services may also be considered misleading practices.
For example: False claims about the quality of a product or service.
Bait advertising and environmental claims.

One is that you can be sold a product under the assumed guise of its being perfectly usable without any additional parts or services. If a cell phone company offers to sell you a phone and nowhere does it state you are also getting a contract and/or sim card, the cell phone will not work, but the company is not obligated to make it work for free. Businesses can also deceive you by selling you a fish tank that does not work without a pump without stating it is necessary-it is sufficient to state on the packaging that a pump is sold separately. This goes for services (in the case of the cell service) and products (the fish tank example).
Some examples of questionable tactics in business advertising are bait advertising, comparative advertising, and green claims.

This would fall under the category of false claims if the business cannot substantiate their promises. If the product promises to aid in weight loss but there is no evidence to support the claim, the user might be entitled to some money back. However, that depends on the fine print-a business can use that space to cite statistics that are either nebulous or true but unsavory or both. For example, they might say something with an asterik along the lines of, "three percent of users see a one pound weight loss in the first five months". Therefore the product does technically work according to their loose guidelines, but that's not a result with which very many users would be happy.

If a company were to advertise a weight loss tea without legitimate scientific support or FDA approval, the advertisement would likely be false or misleading. This might cause consumers to be misled about the efficacy of the product.

If it advertises it as a tea that 'clinically proven to melt fat', this would be an exception to the 'puffery' exception as some fact must be inherent in that claim. Typically, 'natural' or 'organic' claims imply a scientific basis to the claim, and is looked at hypothetically, rather than a claim.

Sabara was a military officer and governor. He was appointed to the position of governor of Southeast Sulawesi in 1966. He was initially intended to serve just one term, but due to a lack of replacement candidates, he was extended for several months. He was appointed acting governor of Central Kalimantan in 1983. He was known by journalists as being the "acting governor specialist" in the early 1980s.

Sabara joined a group of youths from Sulawesi who left for Java to fight in the Indonesian National Revolution. He joined a battalion in the nationalist government. He was imprisoned and was about to be executed before the army freed him during the Madiun Affair. He commanded units within the Hasanuddin Military Region. He was the commander of its Regional Training Regiment by 1965. He participated in the campaign against Andi Aziz's rebellion. He also commanded a reserve brigade during Operation Trikora in 1962.

He served as inspector general of the Ministry of Home Affairs, and became the director general of the ministry's regional autonomy directorate. He was appointed acting governor of Aceh and Central Sulawesi. He revived the deputy governor position in the ministry. He served in the People's Consultative Assembly as a regional representative.

He thinks his job is a waste of time and resources. He is dressed in full uniform, has to have a special security clearance and works in a secret area of a heavily guarded military facility. He was prepared for another uneventful night of watching nothing happen on the monitors.

At 1:07 pm, some of the sensors started to detect something in a pocket of seemingly empty space about 17 light years away. One sensor detects an emission of gamma rays, another one detected x rays. This caught Hunter's attention as it is unusual for an area of empty space to emit such radiation. Hunter decided to take a look at the area with telescopes. He sent instructions an an infrared, visible light, and a radio telescope to survey the area. He was perplexed that both of them showed absolutely nothing even though the radiation levels were reaching levels that were theorized to be the upper limit of what the most powerful stars could emit. Because the telescopes couldn't see anything, Hunter was looking at data that told him a massive amount of radiation was either appearing out of nothing, or leaking into our universe. Hunter decoded that he would restart the sensors and receiving satellites to try and make sure these weren't false readings.

As he was waiting for the sensors to come back on, the infrared telescope he pointed at the area gave an alert. It had detected a momentary spike and drop to normal of heat in the area, which did not match the ever increasing readings from the other sensors. Hunter hoped the sensors would come back on, show nothing, and he could submit a simple sensor anomaly report to his superiors. These hopes were crushed when the sensors started returning information again. Not only did they pick up the radiation again, they were maxed out. Hunter couldn't believe it. He stared in awe, unable to come up with any explanation for what was going on in front of his eyes. Moments later, all the telescopes started giving alerts. The visible light telescope detected light levels akin to a supernova 100 light years away. The radio telescope was showing what could best be described as trying to broadcast every radio station from one antenna. The infrared telescope was telling him that this area of space, empty a few minutes ago, was engulfed in flames.

Then it all stopped. Everything observing the anomaly stopped transmitting data. Hunter thought it was an issue with the receiving satellites, however a check revealed they were functioning properly. He tried restarting the sensors and telescopes, but simply could not get any data from them. Hunter decided this was unusual enough to report to the officers and senior scientists at the base.

He called an emergency meeting, having to wake up generals, astronomers, and physicists in the middle of the night. He thought that his news wouldn't be well received at such a time, however his training told him to go through with the protocol right away. After everyone had been assembled and lots of coffee had been consumed, hunter began to present the data and his recollection of the events. He was surprised as the others began to look horrified.

One of the generals pointed at Hunter and said "Just to be clear son, you can never tell anyone outside this room what you just told us". He then excused hunter from his post, and told him that he would file his honorable discharge papers immediately if Hunter wished to leave the force. "Did I just detect something from out of this world?" Hunter asked the general, to which one of the physicists replied in a solemn tone "Out of this universe".

Bienertia Cycloptera is found in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Turkey, Iran, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. It is also found in the Eurasian supercontinent.

Bienertia cycloptera is located in warm climates. It grows in warm temperatures with little rainfall. It grows in saline and moist clay soils. It is located alongside Climacoptera turcomanica. Bienertia cycloptera is an endangered species.

Other uses of the B. cycloptera are that it has been used in alternative medicine, especially in Persia. It has been used for antimicrobial, antihyperglycemic, and lipo catalytic properties, however there is no evidence to support the claims. B. cycloptera has also been used in scientific research for agriculture for the changing of commercial crops from C3 to C4 photosynthetic plants.

Curzon was the only son of Colonel Alfred Nathaniel Curzon, by his marriage to Henrietta Mary Montagu. He was also a nephew of George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston, head of the family. Curzon's father died in 1920, leaving him as the heir presumptive, and on the death of Marquess Curzon in 1925 Richard Nathaniel Curzon became head of the Curzon family. His inheritance included Kedleston Hall, the baronetcy created for his ancestor Sir John Curzon (1598–1686), and the new title of Viscount Scarsdale.

He had four daughters, but no sons. His eldest daughter Anne Mildred Curzon married Major W. J. L. Willson, and had two sons and a daughter. His second daughter Gloria Mary Curzon married J. G. Neil Malhorta is an American political economist. He is the Edith M. Cornell Professor of Political Economy in the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University, where he is also the Louise and Claude N. Rosenberg, Jr. Director of the Center for Social Innovation. He studies the politics of the United States, survey methodology, and voter behavior in elections, including work on retrospective voting and on the politics of disaster preparedness and relief.

Malhorta has published work on American politics, voting behavior in elections and other forms of political behavior, and the methodology of survey research. His work on voter behavior includes research on the problem of retrospective voting, and how strongly voters consider past events when arriving at a vote choice. Malhorta has also published work on disaster response by governments, and how that response is rewarded or punished by voters.

Hunter started his duty at 11 PM and at 1:07 AM, some sensors at the Array started detecting something in a pocket of seemingly empty space about 17 light years away. So Hunter decided to take a look with telescopes. He sent instructions to an infrared, visible light, and a radio telescope to survey the area. He was perplexed that both of them showed absolutely nothing even though the radiation levels were reaching the upper limit of what the most powerful stars could emit.

The writer used three different components to compose this piece's structure: an important background story which is the inception, or beginning of the invention of Scotch masking tape, the salient details of Richard Drew's life and his work in the University, and the invention of the Scotch tape itself, from inception to conceptualization and the successful release to the populace.

The narrative structure of the informative article follows an origin story centered around Richard Drew and the invention of Scotch tape. The story begins with introducing Drew and explaining the situation in which he made the invention of the tape. The narrative of the article progresses by detailing Drew's method of experimentation and eventual success with the creation of Scotch tape. The article concludes with a brief overview of its success and how it got its name.
She takes the reader through the chronological order of the invention's history and uses corroborating evidence of empirical evidence.

The opening hook of the article teases the origin of the Scotch tape branding. With the reader now interested in the tale, the article proceeds to talk about the inventor of scotch tape, how the tape was invented, and what the inventor did later in their career. Once the entire narrative is finished, it is only then that the writer chooses to resolve original teaser -using its incomplete anecdotal tale as the concluding part of the narrative. By itself, the origin of the Scotch name makes for an interesting hook, but not a satisfying story due to the fact that the information it provides is inconclusive: the story being told is only supposed information. The strongest statement in the opening paragraph may as well be an outright falsification: that the origin of the name is as interesting as the origin of the product itself. So it can be said that the writer of the article turned a mediocre story into an interesting hook for a tale about 3M's Richard Drew.

The text doesn't say much about cyberbullying, but it can be inferred that cyberbullying is the act of taunting or bullying someone through the internet or computer. Cyberbullying is a crime in New York, but the law defining it is vague and leaves a lot of room for interpretation. The New York Senate came up with a solution in SB2318A, but it is vague and leaves a lot of room for interpretation.

The New York Senate came up with a solution in SB2318A. The bill is 12-A. Cyberbullying. 1. AS USED IN THIS SECTION, THE FOLLOWING TERMS SHALL HAVE THE FOLLOWING MEANINGS: A. MINOR SHALL MEAN ANY NATURAL PERSON OR INDIVIDUAL UNDER THE AGE OF EIGHTEEN. B. PERSON SHALL MEAN ANY NATURAL PERSON OR INDIVIDUAL. 2. ANY PERSON WHO KNOWINGLY ENGAGES IN A REPEATED COURSE OF CYBERBULLYING OF A MINOR SHALL BE GUILTY OF AN UNCLASSIFIED MISDEMEANOR PUNISHABLE BY A FINE OF NOT MORE THAN ONE THOUSAND DOLLARS, OR BY A PERIOD OF IMPRISONMENT NOT TO EXCEED ONE YEAR, OR BY BOTH SUCH FINE AND IMPRISONMENT. 3. This act shall take effect immediately. Notice anything missing there? No definition of cyberbullying. Not a good one. Not a bad one. None at all. It’s a misdemeanor to engage in a “repeated course of cyberbullying,” but what that might be is anyone’s guess. The Senate's approach is to leave a huge, gaping hole for prosecutors to fill.

The New York Senate recently passed a bill criminalizing cyberbullying. In doing so, the bill does not specifically define what cyberbullying is, which is confusing for most as it does not specify if cyberbullying can be done against minors or not. It seems that the legislators are passing the bill to try to appear concerned about the youth without actually taking action to protect them.

Arthur Whistler was an ethnobotanist, academic and writer who focused on the flora of Samoa and Tonga. He had first lived in Samoa during the 1970s and trained Samoans on the country's flora and its uses. He authored more than a dozen books on the botany and ethnobotany of Samoa and the Pacific Islands. Whistler died in April 2020 at the age of 75 due to COVID-19. His death was Hawaii's third fatality related to the COVID-19 pandemic. His most famous work is the definitive guide to Samoa's native plants, "Flora of Samoa."

Whistler had seen the adverse effects of logging and tourism in Samoa, and moved there to train Samoans about their flora. He also wrote a book called "Rainforest Trees of Samoa: A Guide to the Common Lowland and Foothill Forest Trees of the Samoan Archipelago".

Whistler had been to Samoa early in his career to teach about Samoan plant life. He had spent two decades in Samoa carefully training locals about the uses of its native plant life, preserving the forest, and resurrecting some of Samoa's lost cultural uses.

There are three physical damage types: Impact, Puncture, and Slash. Physical damage come in ten elemental damage types: four base elements and the six combinations formed by modding two elements together. Elemental damage types are stronger or weaker versus certain enemy types. The physical damage types also have "status effects" that can be applied via a "procedural random chance" percentage, often known as procs. Impact procs make enemies suffer a dramatic stagger, Puncture procs reduce enemies' damage output by a flat 30%, and Slash procs inflict "bleed" damage over time. Slash is considered the most powerful procs from all of the physical damage types.

Nkala was elected chairman of the Bulawayo branch of the African Artisans' Union in 1950. He was elected president of the union in 1956. He served as president of the African Trade Union Congress' Matabeleland region. He was also appointed Chairman of the Barbourfields Tenants' Association and member of the Bulawayo African Townships Advisory Board. In 1957, Nkala joined the Southern Rhodesia African National Congress. He was a prominent figure in the African nationalist movement in Bulawayo. He was briefly detained after a state of emergency was declared by the colonial government in February 1959. He served as treasurer for the Bulawayo branch of the National Democratic Party (NDP) from 1960 to 1961. He was the Bulawayo district chairman for the NDP's successor, the Zimbabwe African People's Union (ZAPU) from 1961 to 1963.

Nkala comes from a large Ndebele family. His father was a peasant farmer, teacher at the local Methodist mission school, and later a cobbler. His mother was a lay preacher of the American-led Brethren in Christ Church. Nkala was raised in the Brethren faith and attended primary school Nkankezi School and at the Church's Matopo Mission. He went on to study at Mzingwane High School in Essexvale. He left behind a widow and five children.

Zofia Nehringowa was a Polish long track speed skater in the late 1920s and 1930s. She represented her nation at the World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Women in 1939 where she finished 5th overall.

The Chungar Mine was named after its location in the high Andes of central Peru. Chungar mine is operated by Volcan through its subsidiary known as Colpañía Minera Chungar S.A.C. The current mines operated by Volcan are known as Mining Units Chungar and Animon. There has been confusion and error made by some sources in regards to the correct name between Chungar mine and Ordim.

The Chungar M ine is an inactive mine that exploited a polymetallic skarn deposit. It is located near Cerro de Pasco, Peru and was destroyed by a landslide-generated wave in 1971. After this disaster, the mining company moved the operations to the Animón mines 16 km NE of the original Chungar Mine. The name "Chungar Mine" has caused some confusion, as the mining company Volcan now uses the name "Mining Unit Chungar" to refer to the Animón mine.

Qonqurtai was a Mongol prince and viceroy of Anatolia for the Ilkhanate khanate. He was born to Hulagu Khan and Ajuja Aguchi, his Khitan concubine wife. He was the senior commander during the reign of his brother Abaqa. He was twice appointed as viceroy of Anatolia. He was appointed as commander of Ilkhanid army in Anatolia with Shams al-Din Juvayni as his vizier. He was executed on 17 January 1284.
Qonqurtai was born to Hulagu Khan and Ajuja Aguchi, his Khitan concubine wife. He was the senior commander during the reign of his brother Abaqa. He was twice appointed as viceroy of Anatolia.

Qonqurtai came from an eventful family. His mother was his father's Khitan concubine wife. Qonqurtai had nine brothers, among whom he was the senior commander. Two of his brothers competed for the Ilkhan's throne - Abaqa and Tekuder. He was married to Toqiyatai Khatun, a Keraite concubine of Hulagu and niece of Dokuz Khatun. His marriage gave Hulagu influence over Toqiyatai's family. Qonqurtai and Toqiyatai had nine children, four of whom died in infancy. After him and his two surviving children were killed, two of his nephews were in line for the throne - Arghun and Ghazan, who were grandsons of Abaqa.

In 1931, Nehringowa rode 10000m speed skating and set the world record. She again set the 5000m world record in 1934. Nehringowa's speed skating career lasted 17 years, during which she always skated at a high level. Nehringowa was Polish champion twelve times and was famous for her racing style. Nehringowa was the first woman to set world records sanctioned by the International Skating Union. All the four of Nehringowa's world records in speed skating were set in 1934. In 1936, Nehringowa was awarded the Silver Cross of Merit.

During her career, Nehringowa set sixteen Polish national records and twelve Polish champion titles. Her records include being the first person to set world records recognized by the ISU, setting records in all individual distances, and setting the 5000m world record.

Zofia Nehringowa was the Polish champion twelve times and won the 5000m national title in 1931 and 1934. She broke the women's world record in the 1500m during the 1932 European Speed Skating Championships for Men in Davos. She set the world records in all six individual distances.

Nehringowa first participated in the Warsaw Ice Skating Society when she was 15 years old. From there she went on to training under Edward Nehring. After Nehring divorced Nehringowa, he married her in his second attempt years later. He had two children with Nehringowa (two sons)  but the two were presumably granted a divorce when Edward turned 35 years old, as he remarried a woman who was 39 years old. Nehringowa, meanwhile, only had two children of her lifespan before she died. In the 1980s and early 90s, ISU accepted women into their competitions, and Nehringowa was "the first woman speed skater in Poland". Nehringowa was a part of the 1932 European Speed Skating Championships for Men, the first women's championship, and the 500m record she set at the time stood for 40 years before it was beaten again by any skater. Nehringowa was also the first person to become a record-breaker recognized by the ISU, but there is a dispute as to whether she set the 5000m record for the international speed skating union.

Nehringowa represented Poland at the World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Women in 1939 where she finished 5th overall.

The term "aquapelago" was introduced by contributors to Shima, an online journal of research into island and maritime cultures.  Aquapelago, as a term, is a collection of marine and land elements that are key to the livelihood of nearby communities as well as their sense of identity. Since the coinage of the term, there has been positive engagement with the term, so much so that the concept has extended into the imaginary and folklore territory where communities engagement with tales of mermaids are being brought into the matrix of aquapelago.

The original definition of aquapelago introduced by Philip Hayward specified their applicability to island communities. Over time, the concept has expanded to consider the role of marine spaces in metropolitan locales, the influences of media-lore on perceptions of the marine environment, and participation in world-making through the imaginary.

"Shima" is now a convened conference on island and maritime cultures. There has been a resurgence of mermaid mythology in pop culture that has been called into question. One essay called the variation of folklore dealing with misunderstood sea-creatures "mermaidlore". The mermaid theme is fairly broad and not directly scientific, but it does seem to be linked to cultures revolving around water areas. It seems bringing together themes of aquapelogistics, historic myths about mermaids, and cultural practices about that around sea territories is a cultural expansion.
At its inception, it was a scholarly concept concerning marine life in the Pacific.

Primož was an important military location during the Second World War due to the tunnels, bunkers and military history. While the tunnels were never used, they could have been of use to military personnel.

Primož is a high hill situated along a ridge that divides the Pivka Basin from the Reka Valley. Because of its military importance during World War 2, a number of tunnels and bunkers were constructed on the hill. Primož served as an important strategic location since from its peak, the entire Pivka Basin could be seen. This importance contributed to its military importance.

Primož is built on a ridge (Javorniki mountain) that separates the Pivka basin from the Reka valley. It contained many bunkers and tunnels used by the Italian army. The edge of the cliff borders the Pivka basin and has commanding views of the valley.

Primož is part of a ridge which separates the Pivka basin from the Reka valley. It possesses a commanding view over the entire Pivka basin, making it an important military location. During the Second World War, it was fortified with tunnels as part of the Alpine Wall, yet they were never used in combat. In total, the tunnels were more than two kilometers long, but they have since been abandoned. Today, it is made accessible by marked trails, with one specifically designated for tourists and containing numerous information signs around its peak. Primož's strategic importance stems from its commanding view and its military tunnels.

Primož hill became Italian territory after World War 1. The tunnels in Primož were built as part of the Italian's defensive long Alpine Wall. The tunnels had two major lines, one running along the border and another several kilometers behind. After the Italians withdrew, German forces destroyed the tunnels so they could not be used against them.

The tunnels were dug as part of the long Alpine Wall. There were two tunnels totaling 5.2 kilometers along with brick-lined access shafts. They were never used for military purposes. They were built in 1930 and secured underground with steel encased in concrete with ventilation pipes and steel plates to prevent damage from aerial bombardment. Primož's military tunnels were destroyed by German forces in 1944.

Since 1930, the tunnels in Primož were dug as a part of the long Alpine Wall, a vast set of Italian Defense fortifications. However, the tunnels were never used for military purposes. Soldiers were periodically garrisoned to guard the tunnels. The tunnels were made to withstand harsh conditions by adding plates to the tunnels and coating them in a thick layer of concrete. There were two layers of tunnels, one on the border and the second one a few kilometers behind it.

Primož is a high hill in the Municipality of Pivka in Inner Carniola in Slovenia. It has many marked trails and a macadamized road leading to its summit. It's a sonnet written in octet with alternating rhyme. Despite its structure being relatively simple, the rhyme scheme is admittedly confusing.

"Reuben Bright" is a Petrarchan sonnet composed of decasyllabic lines of iambic pentameter. Its rhyme scheme is abba abba cdcd ee. The octet is comprised of two quatrains of enclosed rhyme, while the sestet is made up of a quatrain of alternating rhyme followed by a concluding couplet. The poem tells of a butcher, Reuben Bright, and how he reacts when his wife is to die by crying like a baby. When she does die, he packs up her handmade crafts in a chest and adds cedar boughs. Then he destroys the slaughter house. The ironic twist comes at the end of the poem, where the last line reveals he tore down the slaughter house. Overall, the poem's structure follows that of a Petrarchan sonnet and is comprised of an octet and a sestet.

"Reuben Bright" is a Petrarchan sonnet with two quatrains of enclosed rhyme in the octet and a quatrain of alternating rhyme in the sestet. The poem tells the story of a butcher who reacts to his wife's death with the grief of a baby. He packs up all the articles she handcrafted into a chest and adds cedar boughs before he destroys the slaughter house. The twist comes at the end with an ironic twist that reveals sudden depth of feeling in the butcher. The poem's structure consists of a typical sonnet progression with a dramatic turn at the end.
The poem's value lies in the tension between the matter-of-fact language and the psychological depths Robinson hints at. The poem shows a man's deep devotion to his wife.
Initially a love story between Reuben and his wife, it teaches students how transitions between stanzas can shift the main focus of the work.

The poem has been used to be taught to students who might have gotten jaded by traditional sonets. The poem is used to help the students see that poetry does indeed speak to the human condition. The use of common words and not traditional poetic elements helps the student grasp the concept better. Another interesting point is that the poem's ending points to how a butcher has a capacity for deep feeling.
